title: MD, PhD
biography: Christiaan Neethling Barnard (1922–2001) was a South African cardiac surgeon who performed the world's first human-to-human heart transplant on 3 December 1967 at Groote Schuur Hospital in Cape Town. The patient, Louis Washkansky, received the heart of Denise Darvall, a 25-year-old accident victim. Barnard earned his MD from the University of Cape Town and later studied under C. Walton Lillehei at the University of Minnesota, where he learned open-heart surgery techniques. He went on to develop the heterotopic ('piggyback') heart transplant technique in 1974, where a donor heart is placed alongside the patient's own heart — a procedure still used today for certain patients.

awards.name: Dag Hammarskjöld International Prize for Peace
Order of the Star of South Africa

timeline.title: Born in Beaufort West, South Africa
Earned MD from University of Cape Town
Studied Under Walt Lillehei at University of Minnesota
timeline.description: Learned open-heart surgery techniques using heart-lung machines.

timeline.title: First Human Heart Transplant
timeline.description: Performed the world's first human-to-human heart transplant at Groote Schuur Hospital.

timeline.title: Invented Heterotopic Heart Transplant
timeline.description: Pioneered the 'piggyback' technique where a donor heart is placed alongside the patient's own heart.

timeline.title: Passed Away
timeline.description: His techniques remain foundational in modern cardiac surgery.
